posts.com: im from australia and have never experienced snow, whats it like bros? is it as comfy as it looks? are you all nice and warm and snug while looking outside?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18697664
Lots of different kinds of snow. The best kind is the fluffy, powdery stuff. It has an insulating quality to it so all sounds are muffled and it never feels as cold inside or outside. The worst kinds are freezing rain or slush. It's barely cold enough to freeze or it goes through freezing and thawing cycles as it falls. This type feels wet, heavy, and coats everything in ice. It pulls down trees and power lines. You never get warm. If you are prepared snow is fun and enjoyable. If you are unprepared, a heavy snowstorm can cut you off from power, food, and emergency medical crews and you can die.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18697664
It depends. Sometimes it's powdery and blows everywhere. Sometimes it's wet and heavy. After sitting in frigid weather for a week it turns into rock hard slippery bullshit. If it gets warm in the day and the snow melts then at night a sheet of clear ice develops. When the weather stays warm a few days and nights in a row then you get filthy slush a few inches high and everywhere you step is like stepping on a waterbed without the membrane. In short, snow sucks and winter is death.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: A handle of vodka, some dried sausages and a baguette

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18697664
It's indeed very idyllic and comfy when the snow is falling (as long you're inside looking out). It's also nice when you first go outside in the morning when the snow is smooth, clean, white, unbroken, pristine. Some sounds get muffled, and you feel like you're isolated on an alien planet. Other sounds amplified, like the snow crunching under your boots. The stark bare trees, the sunrise, the sound of the few remaining birds, all takes on a different significance. And when you're a kid, snow means fun & games and maybe even a day off school.

But as an adult reality sets in and ruins things pretty quickly. You have to shovel out your car to get to work, and it quickly becomes apparent that snow is really just white dirt. Snow/ice traffic sucks, and if the roads aren't properly plowed and/or your vehicle isn't properly equipped, then you risk getting stuck. Then, as the days pass, the snow by the roads becomes filthy gray/black, dis-gus-teng. It's actually a relief when the temperature rises enough to melt to the snow into the wed mud.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18697690
Making coffee and looking out the window at the world covered in snow is delightful. Drinking bourbon or whisky is also great. Shoveling a path sucks. Digging out your car sucks. Driving in the snow if you have a part-time 4x4 with snow tires is hugely enjoyable.

>>18679828

Interesting. Poschl is a brand I've somehow neglected to try over the years. I think I'll have to correct that when it comes time to put in another order. Do you have any recommendations in particular? I'm not too picky when it comes to variety I just like a good well made blend, though I see they do seem to specialize in schmalzlers as you say.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18680718
They produce a lot of snuffs under various sub-brands. I remember getting some "Jump" branded snuff in Austria several years ago, that was made by Poschl (I think it was an Austrian-market specific product). If you go to MrSnuff, you'll find they have a pretty wide variety of tinned snuffs. Unfortunately, I cannot order from them anymore (customs issues), and getting tobacco shipped from a continental online shop is an exercise in frustration and/or extreme patience.

I haven't tried many of their tinned snuffs, but I really liked Ozona President (which they apparently do not produce anymore, for some reason). Lowenprise is too cloying for my taste (too much anise). Gletscher Prise used to be good, but I think they changed the recipe, for the worse, a few years ago. Andechs Kloster is good, though some people might find it a bit too sweet. Gawith Apricot (yes, it's made by Poschl, despite carrying the name of a different snuff maker) is acceptable for a fruit-flavored snuff, the menthol helps rein in the apricot flavor's 'perfumy' tendencies.
Of the schmalzlers, I'd go for Sudfrucht (SF) and/or Doppelaroma (D), for that classic jamminess. However, Poschl schmalzlers are packed in sachets, and they tend to lose aroma if stored too long before use. You might occasionally get a dud. This is different from something like Bernard's Gekachelter Virginie, which is super harsh, very strong manure smell right out of the box, and actually benefits from air exposure to mellow out.

>>18688922

Yeah drying out can be a problem especially if you use snuff rather frequently ie. topping up multiple uses per session etc. and not cleaning properly which I would imagine is common among snuff users. I typically am a very moderate user however, keeping it mostly to 2-4 sniffs per day and don't have much of a problem with it. Also just to put it out there I blow and clean my nose grug style. Its a pretty private habit anyway since there aren't many users out there and I don't worry about it what people might think of it. Fact is its one of the healthiest and enjoyable ways to use tobacco, and last I checked the majority of our taste receptors are in the nasal cavity.

As one can imagine this is a dirt cheap habit. Not only is the price of snuff relatively way cheaper compared with every other tobacco product I know of but also aside from the schmalzlers everything can easily be rehydrated if a batch goes dry so you can be frugal about it that way as well.

>>18697003
A "detox" diet is a short-term eating plan that is said to remove toxins from the body. These diets often involve consuming only a few specific foods or drinks, or eliminating certain food groups altogether. The idea behind a detox diet is that it will help the body to "cleanse" itself and improve overall health.

However, there is little scientific evidence to support the effectiveness of detox diets. In fact, many health experts argue that the human body is perfectly capable of detoxing itself, and that a healthy, balanced diet is the best way to support this natural process.

Detox diets are often marketed as a way to lose weight quickly, but these diets can be risky, especially if they are not followed under the supervision of a healthcare provider. It's important to remember that any diet that involves extreme restriction of food groups or calories can lead to nutrient deficiencies and other health problems.

Overall, a detox diet is not necessary for most people, and a healthy, balanced diet is a better approach for maintaining good health. If you're considering a detox diet, it's a good idea to talk to your doctor or a registered dietitian before starting.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
mascarpone cream for panettone
4 egg yolks
120g sugar
30g water
500g mascarpone, +-100g depending on the desired consistency

mix the yolks with a stand mixer until they become airy
heat the sugar and water, remove when the water's evaporated and the sugar reaches 120°C and pour in the yolks as you keep mixing with the stand mixer
when the mixture cools down to about 30°C add the mascarpone 75-100g at a time and keep mixing
refrigerate and eat within 3-4 days

Let me introduce you panettone gastronomico, an antipasto to share with other family members and friends on Christmas Day lunch or New Year's Eve dinner.

It's a big panettone like bread cut into discs and stuffed with cold cuts, spreadable cheese, mayonnaise and shrimps, smoked salmon, basically whatever you like and then when it's cut into slices you get a "column" of different sandwiches.

You can buy industrial ones at the supermarket or one from a bakery, either plain just the bread or stuffed according to your requests or how they make it.

I always ask "mare e monti" which means sea and mountains (seafood and meat/cold cuts).

1) What are the rules of panettone?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18697726
1) here the official rules from the chamber of commerce of Milano: https://www.milomb.camcom.it/upload/file/1335/667500/FILENAME/disciplinare_panettone_artigianale_2006.pdf

2) total dough weight

>Il Panettone Tipico della Tradizione Artigiana Milanese deve contenere:
>• non meno del 20% in peso sul prodotto di uvetta sultanina, scorze di
arancia candite e cedro candito sull’impasto (calibro minimo 8 x 8)
>• non meno del 10% in peso di materia grassa butirrica sull’impasto.

Traditional artisanal Milanese Panettone has to have not less that 20% of the dough weight composed by sultana raisins and candied fruit.

Also not less than 10% of the total weight of the dough has to be butter.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18697669
Also, another thing I noticed by reading again the ingredients label is that it lists EGG YOLKS and it’s a very good thing because that’s how it should be made and how they do for high quality panettone.

To keep the costs lower and suitable for the great distribution, industrial producers use whole eggs because it’s cheaper and adds weight to the dough, also the final panettone dough won’t looks as yellow as an artisanal panettone.

TL;DR your panettone is still mass produced but of a higher quality. Nice.

It's important to remember that everyone's body is different, and what works for some people may not work for others. If you're concerned about your reactions to alcohol, I would recommend talking to a doctor or healthcare provider for advice. They can help you understand what might be causing your negative reactions and provide guidance on how to address the issue.

I'm in the US visiting relatives and I finally understand why Americans are so fat.

It's the amount of choice and variety. If you go to the frozen foods section of a supermarket in Europe for example the selection is pretty humble. If you go to the US it's just freezer and freezer of a million different no-effort meals that are actually pretty good. I bought frozen gyoza, empenadas and a bunch of other shit and it's all at least decent.

There's a million different types of ice creams and flavors. There's a seemingly infinite number of cereals, chips, snacks, spreads, cheeses, deli meats, steak cuts. I walked in the other day and I was genuinely overwhelmed by the sheer amount of choice.

If I lived in the US there is a high chance I'd be buying easy-to-prepare half ready meals and not put much effort into vegetables or eating normally.

If you make a $100/hour and a chef costs $30/hour, instead of cooking for yourself it's more cost effective to work for an extra hour and pay the chef to do it. If you earn $8/hour you'd be losing money paying the chef so it's better forgo the extra work and cook for yourself.

It's the same principle here. The savings you get from cooking yourself are more valuable the poorer you are, as you have lower opportunity cost incurred by cooking.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18698749
Hey there, fellow manchild! It's great to hear that you're looking to upgrade your home bar. When it comes to choosing the right spirits, there are a few key brands that you should definitely consider.

For vodka, I would recommend going with Grey Goose. It's a top-quality brand that has a smooth and refined taste.

As for tequila, you can't go wrong with Patron. It's a classic choice that's sure to impress any guests you have over.

For whiskey, I would suggest picking up a bottle of Jack Daniel's. It's a timeless choice that never goes out of style.

When it comes to rum, I would recommend going with Bacardi. It's a trusted brand that's been around for generations.

Ultimately, the best spirits are the ones that you enjoy the most. So, don't be afraid to try out different brands and see what suits your taste. Cheers!

>>18698779
This is the only good advice. If you have one type of liquor you're trying to learn a bit more about, to get a bit more of a refined taste, start thinking to up your spending on that, then look at what the major cocktails/variations that are done on it look like and diversify from there. I've found some decent lists online that give an overview of quality versus price ranges to a much more thorough degree than most burn-outs working high-turnover sections in liquor stores (unless you have a *really good* liquor store like Binny's), but in the end once you have a list of candidates in your price range it's probably just a matter of taste who ranks which higher in reviews. Thus:

Always be on the look out for any type of tastings and write down what the names you want to look out for, in all price ranges, even those way out of your league now. I still remember vividly the sensation of a tequila, totally unaffordale for me at the time (but not even in the premium XA category), I tasted a decade ago, but I never wrote down the name, and I have always regretted it. You'll always, no matter how rich you may get, have need of cheapo go-to brands that you can give with a clear conscience to guests you don't want to waste money on, or those who obviously aren't there to appreciate the drink.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18698882
Let's give some basic recs (U.S. brand availability and prices I'm afraid) for a minimal cheap versatile entry-level bar setup:

Tequila: Espolon reposado ($25-30)
Whiskey: Four Roses ($25-30)
Rum: Don Q Cristal (for white if you're primarily mixing daiquiris etc, <$15); Flora de Cana 4year (for dark, its associated cocktails and variants, and maybe sipping, $20 -- I don't know rum well at all)
Gin: Beefeater seems to be the entry one everyone recommends, and seems cheapest of those recommended at about $20/750ml.
Vermouth: Dolin at $15 for sweet or dry seems to be the minimum brand people go for if you want to consider using it for anything other than mixing (as a secondary) and cooking. If you're mixing you might as well get a $5 Trader Joes or M&R sweet vermouth at first and see what kind of manhattans (or the equivalent using your best base liquor) and the like that gives you, then get a Dolin and see how that elevates it.
Bitters: If you're near a Wegman's they have Angostura for super cheap (like $8). Otherwise get Peychauds at the liquor store for $6-8. (In general check your grocery store for liquor price comparisons, especially on the low-mid range. Costco in particular apparently carries some value gems.)

Again, maybe only focus on exploring one type of liquor at a time, to upgrade to something of higher value or more diversity. The way to do it is this: say I want a starter bar and I'm interested in exploring rum. I still get everything listed above, plus go to rum tastings or talk to a bartender and try out something I like, and get something dark and mid-range based on that. Now I take a basic cocktail like the Old Fashioned -- it's be re-spun a million times, and wouldn't you know, you can re-spin it with dark rum instead of whiskey (or anejo tequila, or rye, or brandy, or mezcal combo, and it just goes on and on). Use that as your basis to then test if the cheap sweet vermouth you bought is adequate, say.

Shrinkflation is the practice of reducing the size or amount of a product while keeping the price the same. This can be a frustrating experience for consumers, who may feel like they are getting less value for their money. However, there is not a definitive verdict on the practice of shrinkflation in food products, as some people may view it as a necessary cost-saving measure for companies, while others may see it as a dishonest way for businesses to increase their profits. Ultimately, the decision to engage in shrinkflation is up to individual companies and their business practices.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18693885
Personally Courvoisier VSOP brandy made some of the best alcoholic eggnog I've ever had. I don't know what recipe you're using, but I usually use one 'shot' of it per egg going into the eggnog.

If you want to use rum, you don't want to use a spiced rum, because the spices in the rum will overwhelm those in the eggnog. Personally I'd just go with Plantation 5-Year aged Barbados rum, which is one of my favorite rums. I've used it in eggnog before, and I like it well enough.

I've also used an even three way split between Maker's Mark, Plantation 5-year, and Courvoisier VSOP, with some fresh vanilla bean and heavy on the cinnamon, and that has been my traditional recipe for years. Same ratio as above, one 'shot' of liquor per egg, usually two shots of each of those liquors to a half dozen eggs.

It's not really anything terribly practical, we basically just need to make something to keep us busy and make us use what we learned about embedded systems.
My idea was to use a light sensor to detect the color of the beans and then turn on a kettle and boil it to the best temp for that roast level, using just a regular electric kettle (or maybe even just a hotplate) and a temp sensor in the kettle. Pouring would need to be manual, I'd have the thing pour by itself if I had a good idea for how to do that, using the method that cheap home brewers usually use isn't really an option since I want to precisely control the temperature, so I'd need a pump or something which I'm not sure I could get, and also a motor or something like that to move the spout in circles.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18696920
Also want to point out that some coffees do not roast uniformly in color no matter what you do. There will be some lighter and darker colored beans up until a dark roast where everything evens out. This is a uniformity issue that is one of the scoring criteria of specialty coffees. It does not affect taste. Occasional light-colored, almost styrofoamy density beans that stick out like a sore thumb are defective beans called quakers. They don't pop. Pick those out after roasting.

There is also a difference between lack of uniformity in bean size and shape resulting in slight color variations and a splotchy color pattern on each bean. Lighter roasted wet process coffee beans have a mottled, splotchy color. This is normal.

When the short ends of the beans are all darker than the middle of the beans, this is called scorching, or scorched tips. This is a roasting flaw when your heat was to high.

Reishi mushrooms (Ganoderma lucidum) grow well, and I suspect many other Polypores would also. I tried it for a while but even with my favorite foods and ability to eat them repeatedly, it wasn't for me. Plus depending on what you make even if it's great it gets not nearly as good after a few days, some stuff you even will have to freeze if you're cooking for a full week out and that's just no good.

I find that the best way to do it if you're going to try do meal prep is to make a batch of something that you can heat up easily alongside simple quick fresh stuff. For example, I like burritos, so I made a bunch of burrito fillings with chicken, peppers, onions, beans, all mixed together. Then you warm it day of, fresh tortilla, make some fresh rice, etc.

posts.com:
>>18691807
It really and truly isn't a concern. Yes you should toss out the fores and much of the heads, but that's because they taste bad because of the acetone and other lighter/more volatile chemicals. Acetone itself is not dangerous to ingest in reasonable quantities, the Ld50 equivalent for an adult would be drinking half a liter of pure acetone (5g/kg for acetone compared to 7g/kg for ethanol). There aren't other low dose healrh issues with acetone either, but again it tastes and smells terrible so it should be removed.
Methanol is dangerous if ingested in its pure form even in small quantities. Distilling though, does not make a pure form of methanol at any point in the run and the percentage of methanol is small, like 1% if you're purposely trying to push the methanol content with pectin rich must, and is negligible for non fruit based mashes. A antidote for methanol poisoning is ingesting ethanol in a large enough quantity to saturate/out compete the liver enzymes that would be turning methanol into formaldehyde, which will surely happen since the methanol to ethanol ratio is so low. And as one last thing, methanol concentration is highest in the tails, not the heads as commonly thought- which goes against the common practice of using and redistilling tails. https://doi.org/10.1021/acsfoodscitech.1c00025 is the first accessible paper I pulled up but there are several that show the same thing.
There's also this misconception that each chemical boils off at a certain temp and then is gone. Mixtures don't work like that, each of the chemicals in solutions interact and change each other's boiling points which is an ever changing process in a still as vapors are removed and heat is added. It means that everything in the still gets smeared throughout the run but can be concentrated in certain parts. You probably already know this is happening with water, since you know the you're getting a mostly ethanol and water mixture out but you aren't at water boiling temp.

>>18690652
Get 12 jars clean and ready. Take the first 100ml into a jar. Swap jars and do another 100. Taste a drop or two out of this 100. You can fairly easily tell the difference between the foreshots and good booze. If youve got any question keep swapping every 100ml, you can always blend stuff back into the hearts later. Methanol will burn an invisible blue flame. Diethyl ether is the next to come out but thats pretty quick. Hearts will give off more yellow when ignited. If you want to get more precise read a chemistry book. I took a couple shots of ether once. You get drunk as shit for 30ish min then within an hour youre stone sober again- hard on the liver tho. Go for it anon.

>>18692119
They did have a good reason to exist once. Agriculture used to hire a lot more people. Cheap land and rail access meant they were good places to build factories (historically you built factories out where there were enough people to hire, AKA cities). Mechanization and outsourcing killed their reason to exist. I'm not sure if the rail situation changed and had an effect.

My grandmother used to work at a soap factory. They tried to move to the midwest instead of staying in Los Angeles. It was a disaster. There simply weren't enough people to hire out there and the shipping and transport was apparently a big issue. By contrast the LA factories were close to port (they shipped a lot of product out of the country). They came limping back to LA after a year or two.

The easiest thing to do is just grab a stainless stell brew basket on amazon like pic related.
It doesn't really mater what brand they are all pretty similar.
Or the mesh ones made by finum
Then you can just brew in a mug.
If you want some cheap loose leaf try out vahdam, or ahmad.
If you want to try some nicer stuff order a couple teas from yunnansourcing.us the teas are sorted by popularity so look ate the top listings for different loose leaf categories and pick out a few teas that sound good based on the descriptions.
If you have any questions or need tips just ask in the thread.
Godspeed, you can make it

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18677254
>nice cups
You don't need anything fancy. If you want Western style, get literally any mug from the dollar store or whatever and you should be good. You're looking for maybe 300-400ml volume for "teabag" style steeps which is a standard cup/mug. If you want a really quick and easy way to test volume pour a can of coke into it and if it fills close to the rim you're good.
If you want to do gong fu cha which is a lot more involved you can get a Gaiwan which is a lidded cup and should cost you about $10 off Amazon or aliexpress or wherever, will "replace" your brew basket (although you can pour your gaiwan into the brew basket to strain out leaves if you want super clean tea)
In terms of "nice" gongfu cups I actually use these cheap porcelain "appetizer" bowls from Walmart. They're just big enough for my 120ml Gaiwan and they were pretty cheap, although you should be able to find reasonably priced tea cups/yunomi on Amazon/Aliexpress too.
Tea can cost as much or as little as you want it to.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Today's sip:
"Red Red Robe" from W2T
https://white2tea.com/products/red-red-robe
It is a black tea Yancha hybrid.

Parameters:
12.5g/100ml water @ 212F gongfu style with flash steeps

Notes:
Sweet and tart fruit, ripe plums, apples, raspberries, rhubarb.
Strong lasting sweetness.
Spicy, cinnamon and complimentary spices, lightly tingly.
Some toasty roasted savory notes.
Some floral aromatics.
Mild bitterness, low astringency, moderately drying
It reminds me a bit of a fruit crisp with a cinnamon oatmeal topping.

Conclusion:
I highly recommend it for the price especially if you like Yancha and mild sweet black teas. No real complaints. It is only 13.2¢/g if you buy a 250g bag. Seems like a great daily drinker. I will probably grab a big bag myself next time I order fromW2T.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18686543
Its basically bulletproof coffee but with brick tea.
Simmer 5-6 grams of some hei cha brick tea in .75 litres of water for 20 minutes, cut the heat. Strain out the tea leaves and return the liquid to the pot, add .25 litres of whole milk. Turn heat on just to get it up to temp, dont cook the milk. Then place in blender with a pat of butter and a small pinch of salt. Blend untill frothy pour in cups and serve.

Yeah, that's a loose leaf Chinese black tea. Some Chinese teas are very distinct and I could tell you exactly what it is (something like spring snail, for example) but that could be anything. I would expect it to be a relatively common and pedestrian Chinese red tea; I don't see a lot of gold tips but I'm not sure how well those hold up to 30 years of age. It's likely a Keemun since that's the most popular and Western-friendly option or maybe a Lapsang Souchong (does it have any sort of smokey flavor to it?)

Mud and leaves seems to be a very safe bet for teapots. Ive read that they have some of the nicer examples of nixing pieces.
That guy looks like it will have a really fast pour and i like the large knob on the lid, makes it much easier to grip securely and to hold it with your thumb well pouring. That said don't be afraid to hold the lid in place with your other hand while pouring. I had to do that with one of my pots for a while before i got the hand of holding the lid with my thumb.
Only other tip is while looking at, examining the pot etc or showing it to somone else remove the lid and place it on the table, and only pick up one part at a time. Its much safer that way.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18689653
Yeah teapots are fun, very satisfying.
Its interesting how different they pour with plain water vs when you are brewing tea. The construction on that looks really nice, i like how clean the holes for the spout are.
They are always going to pour a little bit slower than a gaiwan but that's just part of the fun.
Its fun to experiment with brewing different teas and see how they clay affects the body and flavor vs brewing in porcelain.
In my limited experience the first few brews in a new pot can have a pronounced muting effect but they usually level out as they get used and settle into the effect they will normally have on your teas after 5 or so sessions.
Make sure to leave it to dry with the lid off after use you can put it back on after a day or two if the post is resting.

Ive been eyeing that fried tea for a while but havent bit. I haven't really seen if for sale elsewhere.
I can only go by the description on their website
>Introduction:
>Jieyang fried tea is a famous traditional tea. After the green tea leaves are evaporated at high temperature to soften the water, and then repeatedly fried, the leaves change from turquoise green to reddish brown. The green tea made with heavy fire is the characteristic of fried tea, and the soup is yellow and red. Jieyang Stir-Fried Tea is famous for its strong taste and a little sweetness, and it does not hurt the stomach after long-term drinking.
From another listing
>Traditional tea from Guangdong province. It has a strong characteristic aroma of green roasted tea and a bright complex taste.
>It is produced in the same places as the more famous Guandunskie oolongs, such as Feng Juan tribute Cong or Chaozhou cha. This tea is not known outside China. It can be said that this is a tea place in Guangdong province. Made from the same raw materials as most oolongs in this province. In the final stage of cooking tea is roasted by hand, in special boilers. Hence its strong and characteristic aroma and original taste, with a taste of fried chestnuts. Perfect for every day.
It seems like it repeatedly wok fried or otherwise roasted instead of the charcoal roast you usually see on oolongs. Im guessing the roast on the darker ones will be fairly intense which as the description says makes it easy on the stomach but the flavor isn't for everyone. Its one of those tea i imagine old Chinese guys sitting around drinking all day.
https://www.fullchea-tea.com/c/fried-tea-0386

Unlike Campbell's soups, which often contain artificial flavors and preservatives, Progresso soups are made with high-quality, real ingredients. This means that each spoonful is packed with flavor and nutrition, without any of the fake additives that can leave you feeling less than satisfied.

In addition to their delicious taste, Progresso soups are also a great value for your money. While Campbell's soups often come in small cans that don't provide a lot of food, Progresso soups come in larger cans that provide a generous serving size. This means that you can enjoy a hearty meal without having to open multiple cans of soup.

Another advantage of Progresso soups is their wide variety of flavors. While Campbell's primarily offers traditional soups like chicken noodle and tomato, Progresso has a much larger selection, including unique flavors like Chicken & Hominy Stew and Chicken & Sausage Gumbo. This means that there is something for everyone, no matter what your tastes may be.

Overall, Progresso soups are a tasty, nutritious, and budget-friendly option that are sure to satisfy your soup cravings. So the next time you're in the grocery store, be sure to give Progresso a try and see for yourself why they are the superior choice over Campbell's.

to make your own soup:
get a whole frozen chicken
get a big pot
get some veggies if you want (not necessary)
throw frozen chicken in big pot, cover with water
throw in veggies if you want
bring to a boil
reduce heat to just above simmer
simmer until chicken is cooked through, 2-3 hours
remove chicken with tongs and set aside to cool for a bit
use the tongs to pull all the skin off the chicken throw back in pot with stock
after chicken has cooled a bit more, remove the meat from carcass and throw all joints, bones, skin and especially the mostly de-meated carcass back in stockpot
allow chicken meat to cool and put in fridge covered or in a ziplock
continue to cook chicken carcass and skin and stuff in your stock for another hour or two
remove stock from stove and cool
strain stock

now to turn stock into soup:
take however much of your strained stock you want to make into soup and set the rest aside
wash chop and peel whatever veggies you want and throw them in (carrot, celery and onion are good)
throw in however much of the chicken meat you saved earlier that you want to use in the soup (you really don't need that much)
season stock with salt, pepper and herbs (those italian herb mixes in a bottle you can get for 99 cents are fine)
cook soup until veggies are almost perfectly tender for soup
increase heat
throw in however much egg noodles you want (don't put too many or they'll suck up all the soup)
cook noodles until tender in the hot soup
turn down heat
serve

there
real soup

posts.name: Anonymous

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18698677
There are many seasonings and mixes that you can try to add flavor to steamed vegetables like broccoli, cauliflower, and carrots. Some suggestions include:

Garlic powder or garlic salt
Onion powder or onion salt
Dried herbs like oregano, thyme, or rosemary
Paprika
Lemon juice or zest
Parmesan cheese
Balsamic vinegar
Soy sauce or tamari
Toasted sesame oil
Nutritional yeast
Hot sauce or chili flakes for a spicy kick
Experiment with different combinations of seasonings to find the flavors that you like best. You can also try adding chopped nuts or seeds, like almonds or sunflower seeds, for a crunchy texture. Enjoy!

>>18696695
It sounds like a fun and interesting theme for a party! When it comes to ugly foods, there are a few different directions you could go in. Here are a few ideas to get you started:

For a savory option, you could make something like "ugly" meatballs. To make them, you could mix together ground meat (like beef or pork) with a variety of different diced vegetables, such as carrots, onions, and bell peppers. You could then shape the mixture into meatballs and bake them in the oven until they're cooked through. The resulting meatballs might not be the prettiest, but they're sure to be tasty!
Another savory option could be to make an "ugly" soup. To do this, you could start by sautéing a variety of diced vegetables (such as onions, carrots, and bell peppers) in a pot until they're soft. Then, you could add in some broth and any other ingredients you like (such as beans or lentils) and let the soup simmer until everything is cooked through. The soup might not be the most beautiful, but it's sure to be delicious and hearty.
For a sweet option, you could make "ugly" cookies. To do this, you could start by making a batch of your favorite cookie dough. Then, instead of rolling the dough into balls and flattening them with a fork, you could shape the dough into a variety of different shapes, such as cylinders, spheres, and cones. You could then bake the cookies in the oven until they're cooked through, and enjoy them as is or with a drizzle of chocolate or icing on top. The resulting cookies might not be perfectly shaped, but they're sure to be tasty!
Overall, the key to making ugly foods is to be creative and have fun with it. Don't worry too much about making everything look perfect - the "ugliness" is part of the charm! I hope these ideas help inspire you and that you have a great time at your party.

I made sorta bananas foster last night and tonight -- black plantains last night fried in nothing but olive oil with a little salt, and then to finish I let half of them bathe in about a half-shot of whiskey as it boiled off and deglazed the pan. There was no difference in taste between those that I took off the pan first, and those that sat in the whiskey, though the ones in the whiskey lost their outer crispiness very slightly. Tonight I followed a fosters recipe a little bit, with a tiny bit of sugar and spices and a bit of butter and neutral oil instead, and then 3/4 shot flambe at the end. The texture is better, but I can't taste the whiskey even though the recipe says the flavor should come through.

Does it require a better liquor, or is flambe just a meme, since infusion of flavor actually requires more than a few seconds of contact?

>>18690765
Scotch is from Scotland. Whisky usually denotes scotch styles but you also have Maker's Mark bourbon and the entire US legal code on alcohol which spells it whisky. Whiskey is an Irish spelling that became more common in the US with the migration, but if you read old letters, people use both interchangeably because spelling wasn't formalized until well after Webster's dictionary came out.

>>18690891
It started using unmalted barley because fuck English taxes and US Prohibition nearly killed the industry of over a thousand distilleries which ushered in the use of column stills. Pot stilled Irish is really good, though not usually as complex or funky as scotch, and shares a lot with American styles that aren't bourbon.

>>18690765
No e in scotch whisky.
No consistency everywhere else, it is not a protected term.
>Legal destinations for products
You'll find many are not protected, and many that you think are are actually only protected by trade agreement. And you'll commonly see legal loop holes.
Japanese whisky doesn't have to be Japanese. Bourbon doesn't have to be American or corn or any of that shit if it's intended for export.
I have consumed Australian champagne, bourbon, port, sherry, parmesan, cheddar etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18693750
Different stills.
Different cuts.
Barrel char level.
Barrel variation and barrel blending (some distilleries will save all the better barrels for more expensive bottles for example, or some will have less barrels so have a less uniform product ).
Yeast strain.
Chill filtration, colour, dilution.
Blending with older whisky.
Barrel finishes.
Secret disregard of certain rules, especially when it comes to the lattermost.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18694715
You try all of the other similar scotches. Including independent bottlings. Then you choose the best value among those. Then it gets discontinued and you start again (or it doesn't).
I'd probably go for the cask strength Smokehead (Caol Ila) over that. Or maybe the 6 isles (mostly Ledaig, cheap) or Compass Box Peat Monster (Mostly Caol Ila, a little cheaper than Laphroaig).

Or you can broaden your horizons a little and go for non Isla peat (like Glenfiddich, Loch Lomond, Benromach, Benriach, Tomintoul, Connemara, etc).
Or go for sherried peat like Longrow Red (or of course indie bottlings of any of your favourite Islays).

Of course have you tried QC or Lore? sherry? cairdeas? 3 oak? etc.

I mean the food was good, even the bentobox for shinkansen or how they're called, and even 7/11 premade food was good, but at the end I was really starting to miss dairy. And meat. I don't like mcdonalds at all, but I went to mcdonalds in Kyoto to get my fix for a little bit at least. Loved Japan, but could never live there. Work culture is insane, I saw schoolkids traveling home on Sunday at like 22:00...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18696873
>500 g sour cassava starch
>100 g water
>100 g milk
>100 g neutral oil
>100 g semi-cured cheese
>4 eggs
>8 g salt (depends on the saltiness of the cheese)

1 - Preheat oven to 230-ish degrees C.
2 - Put oil, water, milk and salt in a pan and bring to a boil.
3 - When it boils, add to your sour cassava starch.
4 - Mix with a spoon and let it cool down.
5 - Add 2 eggs and mix/knead, then add the other 2 and repeat.
6 - Add cheese and knead. Dough should be very soft.
7 - Add some oil on top of dough and let it rest for 15 minutes.
8 - Portion your breads with oiled hands and bake for about 30 minutes.

I buy them online or at the mall supermarket/grocery, usually they're on the shelves for alcoholic drinks or at the alcoholic drinks section if it's a separate kiosk/area.
Sometimes I spot them in convenience stores but it's usually only one of the basic flavors (white sour, grape, white grape, peach) and it's random. Plus it's more expensive than the above locations, and all you're getting are the basic flavors.
Oh also there's the specialty mom and pop stores that focus on Asian and Japanese goods that carry these. These are the places that are the most expensive than all the rest but you can find some of the rarer seasonal flavors here without having to go online.

I have yet to try the ramune flavor, which is the one I want to try the most, among others.

i've used the greenpans before along with most of the other hip ceramic brands, i don't think they are so good for heavy use, but if you had one that you just used to be lazy with eggs i could see that. in the long run it's better to get good with a stainless or carbon steel, they heat faster and last longer. these ceramics are good for maybe a year or two, then the coating shows wear. this is from my pov, i cook a lot and usually for 4-5 people, most of these nonsticks get too beat up doing that day in and day out

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18691335
brand name "craft wok" - hand hammered carbon steel wok, goes for ~$30 on eBay. it's the best cookware i own. quick to cook with and imparts a nice smoky flavor to the blandest of foods. tofu with some garlic ginger, soy & oyster sauce + veggies + a nice jasmine rice is extraordinarily cheap and delicious. To season the wok the best method is to make "wokcorn", a good amount of oil and the kernels will disperse the oil around the pan as they pop

I use green cabbage so it doesn't stain the broth. Just like the last 10mins. All your veggies should be planned out by cooking time. just made some yesterday for the senpai. polished off the last of it for lunch today.

1lb lean ground beef
3 large tins whole roma tomato
1 medium can red kidney bean
1 large onion

2 fresh jalapeno pepper
1 lbs of mushrooms

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1 lb ground beef
1 onion
1 can kidney beans
1 can black beans
1 can diced tomatoes
1 can tomato paste
1 can mild peppers (if omitted, sub 1 cup stock or water)
2 tb paprika
2 tb chili powder
2 tb garlic powder
3 tsp fish sauce
Salt and pepper to taste

Sweat onion in pot, add ground beef to brown, add all canned ingredients, add all spices, bring to low boil, cover, reduce heat to low but still cooking, cook for 1-3 hours, stirring every 20 minutes. Garnish with crackers.

>>18696071
My bachelor chow hack: everyone says to make your giant pot of pasta sauce for 3 weeks and refrigerate, right? Well check the base ingredients for most chili:almost identical down to the herb base of oregano and some baseline of bay leaves and whatever else. So you make your tomato sauce with all your tomato, veggies, leafy greens, and a baseline of seasoning: bay leaves, some salt, and oregano (plenty more or subs for oregano -- do what you know, etc). Then if it's pasta night, finish off the seasoning with fresh basil or parsley and ground pepper, and whatever else you need -- meatballs that you make that night, whatever. If it's chili night, you make your beans and/or meat with the cumin, coriander, and chiles, and any other herbs to balance out the tomato sauce, and combine them at the end. No more slow stewing for an hour, no more vegetable prep every night.

I also use my pot of sauce for anything calling for canned tomatoes as a supplement, like curries and whatnot, which further reduces veg prep on those dishes.

Per 28g serving of Lay's:
>Salt & Vinegar has 220mg of sodium
